title: 106_s2310
content: The "Firearms Dealer Penalty Flexibility Act of 2000" allows for the suspension of a firearms dealer's license and imposes civil penalties. Section 923 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to allow the Secretary to suspend or revoke a license or impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations of firearm regulations. The Secretary also has the authority to suspend or revoke licenses and assess penalties for the transfer of armor-piercing ammunition. Additionally, the Secretary can compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for any willful violations. The Secretary has the authority to suspend or revoke licenses and impose civil penalties up to $10,000 for willful violations of firearm regulations, including the transfer of armor-piercing ammunition. The Secretary can also compromise, mitigate, or remit liability for any willful violations. If the Secretary denies an application, revokes or suspends a license, or assesses a civil penalty, written notice must be provided stating the specific grounds for the action. The Secretary must provide written notice stating specific grounds for denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment of a license. An appeal process allows for a hearing upon request of the aggrieved party. The Secretary must provide written notice stating specific grounds for denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment of a license. Upon request, a hearing will be promptly held at a convenient location for the aggrieved party to review the decision. If the Secretary decides not to reverse the decision, the aggrieved party can file a petition with the district court of the United States within a 60-day period. The aggrieved party may file a petition with the district court of the United States for a de novo judicial review within a 60-day period after receiving a notice of denial, revocation, suspension, or assessment. The court can consider any evidence submitted by the parties, regardless of whether it was presented at the initial hearing. The aggrieved party can file a petition for judicial review within 60 days of receiving a notice. The court can consider any evidence submitted by the parties, regardless of whether it was presented at the initial hearing. If the Secretary's action is found unauthorized, the court will order necessary compliance. The Secretary must stay the effective date of any suspension, revocation, or assessment upon request pending an appeal. SEC. 3. TERMINATION OF FIREARMS DEALER'S LICENSE UPON FELONY CONVICTION. Amends Section 925(b) of title 18, United States Code, to change the wording regarding the termination of a firearms dealer's license upon felony conviction.
